title: Power - resistance ratio for 4 W and 6 W at same V

content.question: Two resistors, Resistor <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of resistance <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and Resistor <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of resistance <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, dissipate <math alttext="4 watts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></math> and <math alttext="6 watts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></math> of power, respectively, when each is separately connected to the same source of potential difference. What is the ratio of resistances <math alttext="the fraction R sub 2 over R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
